--- In junit@y..., "Vladimir Bossicard" <vbossica@t...> wrote:
> To solve the problem you have to understand that the framework
creates an
> object for each TestCase 'test' method. The idea is then to store
information
> about the file to execute while creating the TestCase instance (in
the suite()
> method).
>
> One template can be:
>
> import junit.framework.Test;
> import junit.framework.TestCase;
> import junit.framework.TestSuite;
>
> public class BatchTest
> extends TestCase {
>
> String filename;
>
> public BatchTest( String name,
> String filename ) {
> super( name );
> this.filename = filename;
> }
>
> public static Test suite() {
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> for ( int i = 0; i < 10; i++ ) {
> suite.addTest( new BatchTest( "testExecute", "filename"
+ i ));
> }
> return suite;
> }
>
> public void testExecute() {
> System.out.println( "executing: " + filename );
> }
>
> }
>
> Now every test is executed independently from the other and you
will have (in
> this case) 10 different tests executed.
>
> Note that you cannot use the reflection but need to call
BatchTest.suite()
> explicitely.
>
> Is it what you wanted?
>
